trans-unit.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: Choosing a programming language
trans-unit.target: Choosing a programming language

trans-unit.source: Before we go any further, you should know about the programming languages that you can choose from when you develop Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
trans-unit.target: Before we go any further, you should know about the programming languages that you can choose from when you develop Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

trans-unit.source: Although the walkthroughs in this article use C#, you can develop UWP apps using one or more programming languages (see [Languages, tools and frameworks](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn465799)).
trans-unit.target: Although the walkthroughs in this article use C#, you can develop UWP apps using one or more programming languages (see [Languages, tools and frameworks](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn465799)).

trans-unit.source: You can develop using C++, C#, Microsoft Visual Basic, and JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: You can develop using C++, C#, Microsoft Visual Basic, and JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: JavaScript uses HTML5 markup for UI layout, and the other languages use a markup language called *Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML)* to describe their UI.
trans-unit.target: JavaScript uses HTML5 markup for UI layout, and the other languages use a markup language called *Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML)* to describe their UI.

trans-unit.source: Although we're focusing on C# in this article, the other languages offer unique benefits, which you may want to explore.
trans-unit.target: Although we're focusing on C# in this article, the other languages offer unique benefits, which you may want to explore.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your app's performance is a primary concern, especially for intensive graphics, then C++ might be the right choice.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your app's performance is a primary concern, especially for intensive graphics, then C++ might be the right choice.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft .NET version of Visual Basic is great for Visual Basic app developers.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft .NET version of Visual Basic is great for Visual Basic app developers.

trans-unit.source: JavaScript with HTML5 is great for those coming from a web development background.
trans-unit.target: JavaScript with HTML5 is great for those coming from a web development background.

trans-unit.source: For more info, see one of the following:
trans-unit.target: For more info, see one of the following:

trans-unit.source: Create your first Windows Store app using C++
trans-unit.target: Create your first Windows Store app using C++

trans-unit.source: Create your first Windows Store app using C# or Visual Basic
trans-unit.target: Create your first Windows Store app using C# or Visual Basic

trans-unit.source: Create your first Windows Store app using JavaScript
trans-unit.target: Create your first Windows Store app using JavaScript

trans-unit.source: Create your first Windows Phone Store app using C# or Visual Basic
trans-unit.target: Create your first Windows Phone Store app using C# or Visual Basic

trans-unit.source: WinJS on Windows Phone 8.1
trans-unit.target: WinJS on Windows Phone 8.1

trans-unit.source: **Note** For apps that use 3D graphics, the OpenGL and OpenGL ES standards are not natively available for UWP apps.
trans-unit.target: **Note** For apps that use 3D graphics, the OpenGL and OpenGL ES standards are not natively available for UWP apps.

trans-unit.source: If you would rather not rewrite your OpenGL ES code into Microsoft DirectX, you may be interested to know about **Angle**.
trans-unit.target: If you would rather not rewrite your OpenGL ES code into Microsoft DirectX, you may be interested to know about **Angle**.

trans-unit.source: Angle is an on-going project designed to convert OpenGL to DirectX by translating OpenGL API calls into DirectX API calls.
trans-unit.target: Angle is an on-going project designed to convert OpenGL to DirectX by translating OpenGL API calls into DirectX API calls.

trans-unit.source: To learn more, see the following:
trans-unit.target: To learn more, see the following:

trans-unit.source: Angle
trans-unit.target: Angle

trans-unit.source: Create your first Windows Store app using DirectX
trans-unit.target: Create your first Windows Store app using DirectX

trans-unit.target: Windows Store app samples that use DirectX

trans-unit.target: Where is the DirectX SDK?

trans-unit.source: Giving C# a go
trans-unit.target: Giving C# a go

trans-unit.source: As an iOS developer, you're accustomed to Objective-C and Swift.
trans-unit.target: As an iOS developer, you're accustomed to Objective-C and Swift.

trans-unit.source: The closest Microsoft programming language to both is C#.
trans-unit.target: The closest Microsoft programming language to both is C#.

trans-unit.source: For most developers and most apps, we think C# is the easiest and fastest language to learn and use, so this article's info and walkthroughs focus on that language.
trans-unit.target: For most developers and most apps, we think C# is the easiest and fastest language to learn and use, so this article's info and walkthroughs focus on that language.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about C#, see the following:
trans-unit.target: To learn more about C#, see the following:

trans-unit.source: Create your first Windows Store app using C# or Visual Basic
trans-unit.target: Create your first Windows Store app using C# or Visual Basic

trans-unit.source: Windows Store app samples that use C
trans-unit.target: Windows Store app samples that use C

trans-unit.source: Visual C
trans-unit.target: Visual C

trans-unit.source: Following is a class written in Objective-C and C#.
trans-unit.target: Following is a class written in Objective-C and C#.

trans-unit.source: The Objective-C version is shown first, followed by the C# version.
trans-unit.target: The Objective-C version is shown first, followed by the C# version.

trans-unit.source: Now, for the C# version.
trans-unit.target: Now, for the C# version.

trans-unit.source: You'll see that like Swift, the header and the implementation are not in separate files.
trans-unit.target: You'll see that like Swift, the header and the implementation are not in separate files.

trans-unit.source: C# is an easy language to pick up, and comes with the many support classes and frameworks that make up .NET.
trans-unit.target: C# is an easy language to pick up, and comes with the many support classes and frameworks that make up .NET.

trans-unit.source: In no time, you'll be happily writing your code without a square bracket in sight!
trans-unit.target: In no time, you'll be happily writing your code without a square bracket in sight!
